Answer: Hands down, the oral contraceptive pill.Previous to its introduction, a woman could expect to have about 6–10 children during her child rearing years, and the timing of these pregnancies were not predictable. The law of averages meant that at least one of these pregnancies would be complicated and debilitating for many months. This constrained women’s lives in many, many ways. Once women were able to take firm control of their reproduction (the frequency and predictability) their entire way of life changed. We’re talking about half the population of the world.The knock on effects - particularlHands down, the oral contraceptive pill.Previous to its introduction, a woman could expect to have about 6–10 children during her child rearing years, and the timing of these pregnancies were not predictable. The law of averages meant that at least one of these pregnancies would be complicated and debilitating for many months. This constrained women’s lives in many, many ways. Once women were able to take firm control of their reproduction (the frequency and predictability) their entire way of life changed. We’re talking about half the population of the world.The knock on effects - particularly prenatal health care - just radically improved the societies that embraced it. If one looks at any nation on the earth immediately before the introduction of oral contraception versus a few years after its introduction, one sees a dramatic improvement in all elements of society in 100% of the cases.I will say that the Internet is a pretty distinctive second place. The number of lives it affected is the only innovation that comes close to the oral contraceptive pill.
